chapter.title: Geant examples
chapter.para: This document explains the individual geant examples and how to use them. It serves as a first draft version for the geant documentation. All examples should be invoked from the commandline.
Here ist the commandline syntax of geant:

section.title: Getting started
section.para: cd to the examples/hello directory and type 'geant'. You should see the following output:
section.programlisting: Hello world
section.para: Let's have a look at the project file which produces this output:
section.programlisting: <project name="hello" default="hi"> <target name="hi"> <echo message="Hello world"/> </target> </project>
section.para: Since we do not provide a buildfile on the commandline the default name (build.eant) is used. With the option '-b' respectively '--buildfile' it is possible to use a different file. There is no target specified on the commandline either. In this case geant tries to find a 'default' attribute in the <project> element by which the start target for the build process can be specified. When there is no default attribute geant gives up and terminates with the message 'Cannot determine start target.'.
With the option '-v' respectively '--verbose' geant's output is more verbose:
section.programlisting:
Loading Project's configuration from build.eant
Building Project
hello.hi:
[echo] Hello world
section.para: A target can have an optional 'description' subelement which should describe briefly what the target does. It must be the first subelement. In a future version there will be a '--projecthelp' commandline option which will just list all the targetnames with its description without starting the build process.

A <target> element may contain zero or more task elements as direct children. Each task element is executed in sequential order. The specific action which is performed is dependent on the individual tasks.

The only task which our 'hi' target contains is <echo>. <echo> has a single attribute called 'message' and this message is printed to stdout. This is the reason why you see 'Hello world' on your screen.
In the following sections all other examples are explained. We usually do not use 'build.eant' as filename for the examples since we have mostly more than one build file in a directory.

section.title: Variables
section.para: The following example shows how to set and query the value variables. cd to examples/variables and open the buildfile 'variable1.eant'
section.programlisting: <project name="variables1" default="var"> <target name="var"> <description>set and query a variable</description> <set name="who" value="world"/> <echo message="Hello ${who}"/> </target> </project>
section.para: Invoking 'geant -v -b variables1.eant' produces:
section.programlisting:
Loading Project's configuration from variables1.eant Building Project
variables1.var:
[set] who=world [echo] Hello world
section.para: With the <set> task a variable can be defined. The 'name' attribute specifies the name of the variable and the 'value' attribute it's value. The values of variables can be retrieved using the ${<variablename>} syntax. Thus ${who} in the examples returns 'world'.
The value of a variable can be overridden by a -D option on the commandline
'geant -v -b variables1.eant -Dwho=Eiffel' produces:
section.programlisting:
Loading Project's configuration from variables1.eant Building Project
variables1.var:
[set] who=world [echo] Hello world
section.para:
Loading Project's configuration from variables1.eant Building Project
variables1.var:
[set] who=world [echo] Hello Eiffel

section.title: Cascading Variables
section.para: cd to examples/variables and open buildfile 'variables2.eant':
section.programlisting: <project name="variables2" default="var"> <target name="var"> <description>set and query a variable</description> <set name="firstname" value="Bart"/> <set name="fullname" value="${firstname} Simpson"/> <echo message="Hello ${fullname}"/> </target> </project>
section.para: 'geant -v -b variable2.eant' produces:
section.programlisting:
Loading Project's configuration from variables2.eant Building Project
variables2.var:
[set] firstname=Bart [set] fullname=Bart Simpson [echo] Hello Bart Simpson
section.para: This examples demonstrates how variables can be constructed from other variables.

section.title: exec
section.para: cd to examples/exec and open the buildfile 'dir.eant' (for Windows only):
section.programlisting: <project name="dir" default="dir"> <target name="dir"> <description>executes a dir command under dos/windows</description> <set name="directory" value="."/> <exec executable="dir ${directory}"/> </target> </project>
section.para: 'geant -v -b dir.eant' produces:
section.programlisting:
Loading Project's configuration from dir.eant Building Project
dir.dir:
[set] directory=. [exec] dir . Volume in drive D is D Volume Serial Number is 5C52-67D3
Directory of D:\svnstuff\gobo-eiffel\gobo\example\geant\exec
09/08/2002 07:32a <DIR> . 09/08/2002 07:32a <DIR> .. 05/04/2002 01:45p 2,429 build.eant 11/26/2002 08:41p <DIR> .svn 09/01/2001 01:30p 261 dir.eant 09/01/2001 01:30p 519 dir2.eant 09/08/2002 07:32a 875 exec1.eant 09/01/2001 01:30p 251 ls.eant 5 File(s) 4,335 bytes 3 Dir(s) 7,162,626,048 bytes free
section.para: The exec task can be used as a general means to execute a command as one would do on the commandline. This can always be used when there is no appropriate task available. The attribute 'executable' takes the exact string one would specify on the commandline after replacing possibly existing variables.
On Unix call: 'geant -b ls.eant' which produces the same output as a 'ls -l' command on the commandline would show.

section.title: geant
section.para: cd to examples/geant and open buildfile 'geant1.eant':
section.programlisting:
<project name="geant" default="one"> <target name="one"> <description>calls other ant files</description> <set name="who" value="Bart"/>
<set name="buildfile" value="../variables/variables5.eant"/>
<echo message="------------------------"/> <echo message="before call of ${buildfile}"/> <geant file="${buildfile}" target="var"/> <echo message="after call of ${buildfile}"/> <echo message="-------" /> <echo message="before call of ${buildfile}"/> <geant file="${buildfile}" reuse_variables="true" target="var"/> <echo message="after call of ${buildfile}"/> </target> </project>
section.para: 'geant -v -b geant1.eant' produces:
section.programlisting:
Loading Project's configuration from geant1.eant Building Project
geant.one:
[set] who=Bart [set] buildfile=../variables/variables5.eant [echo] ------------------------ [echo] before call of ../variables/variables5.eant Loading Project's configuration from ..\variables\variables5.eant Building Project
variables5.var:
[echo] Hello ${who} [echo] after call of ../variables/variables5.eant [echo] ------- [echo] before call of ../variables/variables5.eant Loading Project's configuration from ..\variables\variables5.eant Building Project
variables5.var:
[echo] Hello Bart [echo] after call of ../variables/variables5.eant
section.para: With the geant task other geant files can be invoked. This can be done in the within the same project scope (default behaviour) or in a new project scope when the 'file' attribute is set to 'true'. At the moment the big difference is that for an invocation in the same scope all defined variables are still available in the called build file. The example makes this visible by displaying 'Hello ${who}' instead of 'Hello Bart' for the first <geant> invokation. The second <geant> invocation passes all variables and thats why you see 'Hello Bart'.
In the future <geant> will be able to take arguments which can be passed to the called build project exactly like you can do it on the commandline already.

section.title: depend
section.para: Demonstrates the attribute 'depend' of targets. cd to examples/depends and open the buildscript 'depends1.eant'
section.programlisting:
<project name="depend_demo" default="C">
<target name="A"> <echo message="A"/> </target>
<target name="B" depend="A"> <echo message="B"/> </target>
<target name="C" depend="B"> <echo message="C"/> </target>
</project>
section.para: 'geant -v -b depends1.eant' produces:
section.programlisting:
Loading Project's configuration from depends1.eant Building Project
depend_demo.A:
[echo] A
depend_demo.B:
[echo] B
depend_demo.C:
[echo] C
section.para: With the XML attribute 'depend' targets can be made dependent on another. In the example target 'C' is dependent on target 'B'. This means that target 'B' will be executed before target 'C' is executed. It is possible to specify more than one target dependency using comma separated target names in the 'depend' attribute:
section.programlisting: <target name="C" depend="B,A" > <echo message="C" /> </target>
section.para: This means that target 'B' is executed first, then target 'A' and then target 'C'.

section.title: conditional/if,unless
section.para: Demonstrates the optional 'if' and 'unless' XML attributes of targets.
cd to examples/conditional and open buildfile 'if1.eant'
section.programlisting:
<project name="if_demo1" default="C">
<target name="A" if="$runa"> <echo message="A"/> </target>
<target name="B" if="${runb}"> <echo message="B"/> </target>
<target name="C" depend="A,B"> <echo message="C"/> </target>
</project>
section.para: 'geant -v -b if1.eant' produces:
section.programlisting:
Loading Project's configuration from if1.eant Building Project
if_demo1.C:
[echo] C
section.para: As values of the 'if' and 'unless' XML attributes of target elements you can use variable values and environmentvariables. This means the 'if' attribute returns true if the variable is defined otherwise true. The value of the variable does not matter. The same is true for 'unless' except that it returns true if it is not defined.
Since the variables 'runa' and 'runb' are not defined target 'A' and target 'B' do not produce any output.
e_you_like' produces:
section.programlisting:
Loading Project's configuration from if1.eant Building Project
if_demo1.A:
[echo] A
if_demo1.C:
[echo] C
section.para: geant -v -b if1.eant -Druna=any_value_you_like -Drunb=another_value_you_like
section.programlisting:
Loading Project's configuration from if1.eant Building Project
if_demo1.A:
[echo] A
if_demo1.B:
[echo] B
if_demo1.C:
[echo] C
section.para: As you can see the if's return true and targets 'A' respectively 'B' get executed.
The file unless1.eant contains the same examples but the if's have been replaced with unless's.

section.title: conditional/if2
section.para: Demonstrates how we can use 'if' and 'unless' to create a os independent buildfile. cd to examples/conditional and open buildfile 'if2.eant':
section.programlisting:
<project name="if_demo2" default="list">
<target name="list_for_windows" if="$WINDIR"> <exec executable="dir"/> </target>
<target name="list_for_unix" unless="$WINDIR"> <exec executable="ls -l"/> </target>
<target name="list" depend="list_for_windows,list_for_unix"> </target>
</project>
section.para: 'geant -v -b if2.eant' produces (windows only):
section.programlisting:
Loading Project's configuration from if2.eant Building Project
if_demo2.list_for_windows:
[exec] dir Volume in drive D is D Volume Serial Number is 5C52-67D3
Directory of D:\svnstuff\gobo-eiffel\gobo\example\geant\conditional
09/03/2002 08:15p <DIR> . 09/03/2002 08:15p <DIR> .. 11/26/2002 08:41p <DIR> .svn 11/11/2001 10:58p 261 if1.eant 11/11/2001 10:58p 316 if2.eant 11/11/2001 10:58p 593 if3.eant 11/11/2001 10:58p 925 if4.eant 05/12/2002 05:30p 724 if5.eant 09/03/2001 05:58p 271 unless1.eant 6 File(s) 3,090 bytes 3 Dir(s) 7,162,556,416 bytes free
if_demo2.list:
section.para: Note: for simplicity we assume here that if a environment variable 'windir' exists that we are in a windows environment. Otherwise we are on unix. This should be ok for most situations.
File if3.eant basically has the same behaviour but introduces an additional abstraction layer by introducing some variables defining the operating system:
section.programlisting:
<project name="if_demo3" default="list">
<target name="windows" if="$WINDIR"> <set name="os.windows" value="true"/> </target>
<target name="unix" unless="$WINDIR"> <set name="os.unix" value="true"/> </target>
<target name="init" depend="windows,unix"> </target>
<target name="list_for_windows" depend="init" if="$os.windows"> <exec executable="dir"/> </target>
<target name="list_for_unix" depend="init" if="$os.unix"> <exec executable="ls -l"/> </target>
<target name="list" depend="list_for_windows,list_for_unix"> </target>
</project>

section.title: thread
section.para: For tasks which are thread-capable, there are several ways to indicate the maximum number of threads that this task should use. With no explicit indication, the task will use its default maximum number of threads (which most of the time will be the number of CPUs - 3, or 1 if the resulting number is not positive).

These defaults can be overridden on a task by task basis using the attribute thread. For example:
<gec ... thread="4"/>

These defaults can also be overridden globally using geant's command-line option --thread. For example:
geant --thread=4 compile
Note that the command-line option --thread takes precedence over the tasks' attribute thread. Also, specifying a negative number -N for the number of threads means "number of CPUs - N".
The tasks which are currently thread-capable are <gec> and <gecc>.
